text:
By the way. Does anybody know if HMR is supporting rolling back changes? Cause, I'm using it in production and I need this feature very much.

I've figured out that `webpack.records.json` file has property called `prepreHash`, and I think it could be useful for rolling back already applied changes. But there are no docs at all, that describe records file syntax. There is just a few words about this in webpack 1 docs: https://webpack.github.io/docs/configuration.html#recordspath-recordsinputpath-recordsoutputpath and no docs at all in webpack 2: https://webpack.js.org/configuration/other-options/#recordspath

Can someone help me, please?

Would also like a second opinion on my finding, as far as I understand, https://webpack.js.org/guides/code-splitting-async/#components/sidebar/sidebar.jsx, as per the docs, `import(/* webpackChunkName: "my-chunk-name" */ 'module');` as far as ive seen and understand there cannot be a space between the comment and the module. but the docs look like they have a consistent space enforced between the chunk name and the module.

Thanks
html:
Would also like a second opinion on my finding, as far as I understand, https://webpack.js.org/guides/code-splitting-async/#components/sidebar/sidebar.jsx, as per the docs, import(/* webpackChunkName: "my-chunk-name" */ 'module'); as far as ive seen and understand there cannot be a space between the comment and the module. but the docs look like they have a consistent space enforced between the chunk name and the module.

Thanks

@sstern6

are all doc PRs done on webpackjs.org, or are there other repos where documentation is updated?

It's a mix... all loader and plugin readmes in the webpack-contrib organization's repos (and a few external repos) are pulled during the build. Issues and PRs to correct those documents would have to happen outside of the main repository. The voting app and analyze app are also external. Everything else though should be edited in the content directory. On the loader and plugin pages, there is a Jump to Repository and Edit Document pages that will bring you to the right place. You can also ping us if you're still unsure.

... as per the docs, import(/ webpackChunkName: "my-chunk-name" / 'module'); as far as ive seen and understand there cannot be a space between the comment and the module...

Do you get an error when excluding the space? I'm using import() on a few projects and haven't seen any issues although I typically write it out like this:

import(
  /* webpackChunkName: "my-chunk" */
  './path/to/some/file'
)

app.component.ts


import { Component } from '@angular/core';
import {Subject} from 'rxjs/Subject';

@Component({
  selector: 'app-root',
  templateUrl: './app.component.html',
  styleUrls: ['./app.component.css']
})
export class AppComponent {
  title = 'AppDynamics Sample App for Angular 2';

    click = new Subject();

    ngOnInit() {
      this.click.subscribe(console.log);
    }


}

Under `modules`, there must also be something like,
```
      {
        test: /\.vue$/,
        loader: 'vue'
      },
```
In cases of vue and one other example is postcss, we can give additional configuration to the loader by creating another object within webpack conf.

Is webpack smart enough to know that two definition arrays used in diferent modules can be the same chunk? Example:
moduleA:    require([jquery,bootstrap,backbone],function(){})

moduleB: require([jquery.bootsrtap,backbone],function(){})

moduleA: require(["jquery"], function($) { require("backbone") })
moduleB: require(["jquery", "backbone"], function($, bb) {})
